citations.narrative:
On the morning of October 21, 2024 at approximately 7:30 am a keeper on thier morning checks found that the female
Tawny Frogmouth was killed overnight by what the zoo thinks is a possible mink. The male Tawny Frogmouth and
Kookaburra housed with the female Frogmouth that was killed, were unharmed and moved inside to their winter primary
enclosure. Some feathers were located beside a gap under the wooden fence along the back of the primary enclosure
and could be one of the areas the possible mink could have entered/exited. The bird carcass was gone, and there were
no tracks or other clues to identify what predator came into the enclosure and killed the Tawny Frogmouth. The zoo has
had problems with mink this year and currently has been trying to remove them from the property.
The primary enclosure has housed these birds for several years and have not had any previous issues, however the mink
problem this year is new. The enclosure was originally used to house other mammals in the past, and was updated to
house birds. However there were several areas within the primary enclosure that could allow for entry of a small, narrow
predator like a mink that can be dangerous for bird species in captivity that can not fly away from the danger. There were
areas around the rocks bordered by the wooden wall and areas along the ground level at the base of the wooden wall and
an open knot hole at the front wooden wall that allowed spaces of over 2 to 3 inches wide or long where an animal like a
mink could gain access into the enclosure.
While the birds had been safe for several years in this type of enclosure that was modified from mammals to birds, it did
not account for the gaps around the rock feature or between the wooden wall base along the ground that were wide
enough to allow smaller predators access to the regulated animals.
The lack of secure predator proof enclosures for bird species can cause possible stress to the animals by allowing
predators to enter the primary enclosures to harass, injure or kill the regulated species.
Housing facilities for birds must be designed and constructed so that they are structurally sound for the species of bird
housed in them. They must be kept in good repair, protect the birds from injury, and restrict other animals from entering
that may negatively affect the welfare of the birds within.
To be corrected by: This was corrected on October 21, 2024 before the inspection with the remaining birds being moved
into their indoor winter primary enclosures.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representative.
